history.content:
I try to space them out over sessions. Like 2 units in session A, 4 units in session C. There may a week or two where things get crazy but thats about it.

-------

Well, what a difficult schedule is depends on both the courses and the person.

With some exceptions, the usual rule of thumb is that a summer course is twice as hard as a course in a regular semester. So, talking generally and without knowing more about your situation, taking 2 courses during the summer is comparable to taking 4 courses during the semester, and not uncommon.

But also note that not all summer courses are run simultaneously. For example, CS courses are during session C (the latter 8 weeks of the 12 weeks of summer courses). So, if that's your busy course, you can pair it up with a course during session A (the first 6 weeks), and only have 2 weeks of overlap.
I try to space them out over sessions. Like 2 units in session A, 4 units in session C. There may a week or two where things get crazy but thats about it.

I'm interested in taking classes over the summer. However, I hear that it's discouraged to take more than one class, since a single 4 unit class is enough to eat up all my time during the summer. How can you reconcile this with the 6 unit minimum required for financial aid?
history.subject: Unit Requirement for Summer Financial Aid
